metadata.title: Ross Sea Food Web - Ocean Adventurers
metadata.description: Explore the Ross Sea ecosystem with challenging questions about Antarctic marine life.
metadata.subject: Marine Biology

questions.question: Which animals form the largest biomass in the Ross Sea food web?
questions.explanation: Krill form enormous swarms and represent the largest biomass in Antarctic waters. A single swarm can contain millions of individuals and stretch for kilometers!

questions.question: The whale above has teeth. What is its main prey?
questions.explanation: Sperm whales and other toothed whales dive deep to hunt giant squid. Some battles between sperm whales and giant squid leave scars on the whale's skin!

questions.question: Why are phytoplankton called 'primary producers'?
choices: They produce their own food from sunlight
questions.explanation: Phytoplankton are primary producers because they convert sunlight into food through photosynthesis, forming the base of the ocean food web.

questions.question: How do baleen whales feed differently from toothed whales?
choices: They filter small organisms from water
questions.explanation: Baleen whales have comb-like plates that filter huge amounts of water to catch tiny organisms like krill, while toothed whales hunt individual larger prey.

questions.question: What role do these organisms play in the ecosystem?
questions.explanation: Bacteria are decomposers that break down dead organisms and waste, recycling nutrients back into the ecosystem for primary producers to use.

questions.question: Which predator is known for stealing penguin eggs and chicks?
questions.explanation: Skuas are aggressive seabirds that prey on penguin eggs and chicks. They're opportunistic feeders and play an important role in the Antarctic ecosystem.

questions.question: Why is overfishing of toothfish a concern for the Ross Sea ecosystem?
choices: They're top predators that control fish populations
questions.explanation: Toothfish are apex predators. Removing too many disrupts the balance by allowing their prey species to multiply unchecked, affecting the entire food web.

questions.question: What connects all organisms in this Antarctic food web?
choices: Krill as a key food source
questions.explanation: Krill are the keystone species connecting primary producers to higher predators. Most Antarctic animals either eat krill directly or eat animals that feed on krill.

questions.question: These bottom-dwelling creatures feed on what?
questions.explanation: Benthic invertebrates feed on 'marine snow' - dead plankton, feces, and other organic matter that slowly sinks to the ocean floor from the waters above.

questions.question: Which animal above can dive deepest in search of food?
questions.explanation: Elephant seals can dive over 2,000 meters deep and hold their breath for up to 2 hours while hunting for deep-sea fish and squid!

questions.question: In winter, what happens to phytoplankton populations?
choices: They decrease due to less sunlight
questions.explanation: Phytoplankton populations crash in winter when there's no sunlight for photosynthesis during the polar night, affecting the entire food web.

questions.question: How many penguins can a leopard seal eat in one day?
questions.explanation: Leopard seals are fierce predators that typically catch 1-2 penguins per day. They wait near ice edges where penguins enter and exit the water.
